title: 103_hr181
content: The Act titled "Notch Baby Act of 1993" establishes a new guaranteed minimum primary insurance amount for those eligible during a transitional period. The "Notch Baby Act of 1993" introduces a guaranteed minimum primary insurance amount for eligible individuals during a transitional period. Amendments to the Social Security Act include calculating the primary insurance amount with a transitional increase based on former law and applicable percentages. The "Notch Baby Act of 1993" establishes a guaranteed minimum primary insurance amount for eligible individuals during a transitional period. The primary insurance amount is calculated with a transitional increase based on former law and applicable percentages ranging from 60% in 1979 to 10% in 1983. The term 'excess under former law' refers to the difference between the former law primary insurance amount and the amount calculated under current regulations. The amendments made by the "Notch Baby Act of 1993" are effective as if they were part of the Social Security Amendments of 1977. Monthly benefits under title II of the Social Security Act will not increase before January 1994. Recomputation of benefits is required for individuals entitled to monthly insurance benefits in December 1987 based on specific criteria outlined in the Act. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will recompute the primary insurance amount for individuals entitled to monthly insurance benefits in December 1987 based on specific criteria outlined in the Act.
